1121495185785888769.text:
You can't make isolated decisions about censorship and expect them to hold up.  Censorship is a liquid, it flows from those with power onto those without.

Advocating for institutionalized censorship of (almost) any form is misguided and, at best, a wasted effort.

1121494367703715840.text: I get why some are criticizing this thread as centering white supremacists, but I have skin in the game here, and it isn't aligned with defending those assholes. So perhaps take that into account.

1121493805859926016.text: I have consistently centered sex workers and queer people in my work since I started working in this space. I have entire essays/threads on that topic and a book. My org @OpenPriv works with those communities to build tools to resist censorship of those communities directly.

1121491534560391168.text: White supremacists have power because a not-insignificant portion of the population gives them that power. You can't directly censor power. Trying only normalizes censorship as a practice, and that ultimately harms communities with less power.

1121490020727025664.text: White supremacy is rooted in colonialism which feeds all manner of bigotry from homophobia & transphobia to sexism & violence against sex workers. I'm not interested in having philosophical debates on tolerance, I'm interested in how power accumulates and is exercised in systems.

1121489124966354944.text: Let's pretend that as someone who intersects with a few marginalized  communities, and who works with marginalized communities on the receiving end of fascism and as someone who once took a 2 year philosophy course, that I am familiar with Popper & move the dialogue on further.

1121484596900577280.text:
Here are your options: 

1) Twitter as a public utility, where the majority of, sometimes reprehensible, speech is defacto protected.
2) Twitter as a private corporation, making arbitrary decisions about protected speech based on popular opinion.

1121482675427004417.text: Sex workers and queer people are already facing an unprecedented online censorship campaign because of bullshit US laws loosely interpreted by corporate council. The solution to that is not more institutionalized censorship.

1121481612816834560.text: When we decide that it is OK for a platform like twitter to ban elected politicians, we are setting precedents around how corporations should moderate public discussion, even that they should moderate public discussion.

1121480759913488386.text: A few weeks ago I had coffee with a civil liberties lawyer & we had an interesting discussion about one of the greatest fears they have is the movement of activity from public spaces ("rights space") to private spaces ("no-rights space") - the power we give corporations matters.

1121480031551643648.text: As someone who has been on the receiving end of hate speech both online and offline - hate speech is speech. I don't like it, but there are more effective ways of dealing with those kinds of people.

1121478882945691648.text: You want to block stuff, go ahead. You want to advocate for removing power from certain people, go ahead. You want to go punch some white supremacists, go ahead. But stop institutionalizing censorship in our communications.

1121478092239716352.text: Twitter would be completely within their rights to ban white supremacists including politicians, but it would be a very bad idea for both Twitter as a corporation and the general standard of protection of speech in free societies.

1121474298093293568.text: Banning *democratically elected representatives* from a defacto-public forum because they echo ideas that are reprehensible to a large number of people is a terrifying precedent to set, and probably the strongest argument for regulating twitter as a public utility.https://twitter.com/donttrythis/status/1121461096697589760 …

1120556043455664128.text: The entire goal of the coaching session is to answer the question "what do I do next". The coach doesn't attempt to solve the problem, they simply asks a series of questions to aid their clarification and prompt the coachee to delve deeper. That's it.

It is 2019, election hacking is a very real risk. Most of the adversaries that you have to worry about are not a tiny team of sleep-deprived academics and underfunded non-profit researchers.

Let's be brutally honest here, our team did amazing work, but it's a drop in the ocean.

1109913272537346048.text:
I wasn't asking a hypothetical (https://twitter.com/SarahJamieLewis/status/1106974216090341376 …)

We have found critical issues in 2 major components of this system, and...*counts on fingers*...all of them if you count the many soundness issues in the other ZKP implementations.

And +1 if you count the dead OR Proof.

1109912775860449280.text: I can confirm that @matthew_d_green was wrong about this one.https://twitter.com/matthew_d_green/status/1097568577958412289 …

1109912635800059904.text:
Many of these issues are not exploits in themselves, but are indicators of insufficient skill/attention/auditing in the design, implementation and checking of the system. None of these should have survived a competent audit.

(How many audits has this system gone through again?)

1109912325413195777.text: Finally, the underlying proof framework that drives many of the ZKPs uses a non-collision resistant hash function. One of the key assumptions for the soundness of non-interactive ZKPs is that the hash function must act like a random oracle. It does not.pic.twitter.com/TpcYkCRBhU

1109912097192710145.text: Interestingly the presence of the OR Proof seems to violate the swiss evoting ordinance: "The documentation on the system and its operation must explain the relevance of the individual components of the source code for the security of electronic voting". https://www.admin.ch/opc/en/classified-compilation/20132343/index.html#a7b …

1109911979966128128.text: Anyway, this OR Proof was missing a vital check in the verifier that resulted in it just not functioning at all. As I said before, this was completely dead code. But very broken dead code nevertheless.pic.twitter.com/RVfEgJpKAk

1109911371141910528.text: The above commitment was from an email I sent Scytl asking if the OR Proof had ever been used as I was concerned that (like as happened before with the Shuffle Proof) that non-Swiss evoting code had also been released along side the Swiss code.

1109911237729476608.text: echo -n "I'll be concise and to the point, and in good faith I will tell you that I think there is an issue in your OR proof construction (com/scytl/cryptolib/proofs/maurer/factory/ORProofGenerator) - 2019-03-14" | sha256sumhttps://twitter.com/SarahJamieLewis/status/1106226496048230400 …

1109911157777661952.text: One of the first issues I found in the code was a critical break in the OR Proof construction (which reduces it to not-a-proof at all). Why is there an OR Proof in this code? Great question! Scytl confirmed to me via email that it had never been used in a real system.

1109911032900677632.text: The weak Fiat-Shamir transform leading to the Decryption Proof break impacts many of the other ZKP implementations (they all share a common base implementation) - we show how this impacts the soundness of the Schnorr Proof (this likely cannot be exploited in Swiss Post)pic.twitter.com/MN8kiNyKzE

1109910431529734144.text: The following tweets are a summary of the other issues that we found that we are publicly disclosing today. Some are implementation issues that may impact soundness, some are...well I'll get to them.

1109910142210854912.text:
In my opinion, it is important to understand this issue in context, which is one of the reasons we are also releasing details of a number of other major issues that we found with the zero knowledge proofs in the system.

1109909141131161600.text: Starting with the critical issue: we found a flaw in the Decryption Proof in the system that would allow an insider to spoil votes for candidates they didn't like and, as in the case of the previous shuffle proof issue, create a "proof" that said they had done no such thing.

I've used this example before, but I'm going to again. Go look at the BulletProofs paper and compare it to https://github.com/dalek-cryptography/bulletproofs … - now do the same for the BayerGroth/Scytl spec and compare it to the Scytl ShuffleProof.

Tell me which one you expect is easier to review.

1106590141231955968.text:
Even if the person who wrote the code had a complete working model of the BG proof in their head as they wrote it, what they wrote does not easily map to the spec.

It would be interesting to know how many times the Shuffle Proof code has been reviewed like we did.

1106588798840795136.text:
We had combined knowledge of reverse engineering complex java code, cryptographic expertise, a specific attack in mind and environments where we could run and step through various parts of the code.

It took us 10 days to demonstrate an attack. The code is hard to audit.

1106587033902813195.text: After all was said and done, I think our false proof generation code required only 20-30 lines to change, but those lines were split over a dozen different packages.

1106587033017815047.text: Our initial break was a dummy attack that just demonstrated we could break the verifier in-principle. Even after those 4 days were up, we still spent a solid week working on generating proofs that resembled the attacks described in the paper.https://twitter.com/SarahJamieLewis/status/1099765024204120065 …

1106586024212258816.text:
While the Scytl spec can fit on a page, the implementation spans 20+ different classes, core functionality that is only needed one is squirreled into helper classes instead of inline.

Abstraction choices make analyzing behavior of a given function difficult.

1106585173720612865.text: To make matters worse, the code attempts to write the code in a way that decouples various aspects (I think for parallelization), and so provides a "harvester" construct that allows values to be generated in one class and reappear somewhere else - very difficult to trace.

1106583322841374721.text: To give an example, let me provide some more insight into what it took to generate the cheating proofs we provided with our analsysis: https://people.eng.unimelb.edu.au/vjteague/SwissVoteTestTwoCheats.zip …

1106582816085557248.text: Some people have criticized me for making a big deal out of a  "simple" bug - but I will keep hitting home that this really isn't about the bug, the bug is bad, sure, but I think the bigger concern is a code base that makes these bugs easy to introduce, and hard to find.

1106581498704986112.text:
So, my main question is not about the implementation or even the spec. We know both had this trapdoor. My main question is was this caught in a previous audit, as Swiss Post seemed to say, or not?

If, yes, why was it not fixed?

If, no, was this spec/code reviewed at all?

1105497253056176128.text: Good Morning Everyone, I have now had a few hours of sleep. I will wade into my messages later. For those on the west coast who didn't stay up most of the night, here is my thread where I summarize my thoughts on the trapdoor we found in the proposed swiss #evoting system.https://twitter.com/SarahJamieLewis/status/1105378257317191680 …

1105395544778670080.text: Statement from the Swiss Federal Chancellery on this issue: https://www.bk.admin.ch/bk/de/home/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-74307.html …

1105392632929243138.text: I should also add that even though, according to some Swiss media over the last few weeks, I "look like someone who would have been burned at the stake" I want to assure you all that this isn't deep magic, it's just math.

1105391440698400769.text: Probably worth linking to the thread that started me down the path that lead to many long nights of analyzing code:https://twitter.com/SarahJamieLewis/status/1097223122405646336 …

1105387409716404225.text: Amazing how quickly "people in unofficial channels who don't understand cryptography" becomes "We are thankful to those researchers who helped us identify this issue "

1105385191814553601.text: The answer is yes. I do. They are not as critical as this issue, but they are there. This code is simply not up to the standard we should require of critical public infrastructure.

1105384926944194561.text:
Interestingly I've talked to several journalists today & not one asked me what I think is one of the more interesting questions:

"Do you know of other issues in the code?"

1105384381768581120.text: I'm not here to tell you what to think, but I am here with a whole list of questions that I think are very important to answer if governments are really serious about giving these evoting systems the power to decide who controls a nation.

1105384053904011264.text: And it is worth pointing out that this is bigger that Switzerland. Other countries are moving towards evoting, many are adopting systems that are related to this code base (how they are related is another big question worth asking).

1105383719903232000.text: Why did previous audits not catch this? If they did, as is claimed, why does the issue still exist 2-3 years later? Are those answers true for the many thousands of other lines of code?

1105383364343676928.text: I can't tell the people of Switzerland what to do. They have to guide their own democracy. But I can suggest, that given the circumstances, they investigate mechanisms to halt further adoption (https://evoting-moratorium.wecollect.ch/de ) until the many critical questions have been answered.

1105383052132392960.text: I see that the official spin on this whole thing is that this was a successful result of the public intrusion test. I disagree completely with that characterization.

1105382574241665024.text: Media Break: Some more analysis of this finding from @RepublikMagazinhttps://www.republik.ch/2019/03/12/gravierender-mangel-am-e-voting-system-der-post-entdeckt …

1105381800585584640.text: Let us not downplay this. This code is intended to secure national elections. Election security has a direct impact on the distribution of power within a democracy. The public has a right to know everything about the design and implementation of the system.

1105381565062819840.text: Media Break: This article by @KimZetter about this research:https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/zmakk3/researchers-find-critical-backdoor-in-swiss-online-voting-system …

1105381199483006976.text: That last point is very important in the context of an issue like the trapdoor we discovered. Do not let people minimize this issue. This isn't "some random hacker can steal an election" this is "SwissPost can prove they didn't steal an election, even if they did"

1105381090288517120.text: We need to understand that it is unacceptable that the same organization that stands to benefit from running evoting infrastructure should be in a position of deciding what and when researchers can disclose issues.

1105380843873218560.text: As I stated, we did not participate in the bounty. I feel that Swiss Post's terms and conditions were & are incompatible with the necessity for the public to be told about critical issues, like this one.

1105380758930173952.text: If we really are set in living in a world with evoting then we need to come to terms with the scale of the challenge, understand that puffery, redacted audits and bug bounty marketing stunts have no place in building secure infrastructure.

1105380381824495616.text: As researchers we have spent a lot of time over the last few weeks working on this, but we still only focused on a small portion of a much larger system. There are very important questions to be asked about what other issues lurk in both the specification and the implementation.

1105380259950604288.text: So how did this trapdoor come to exist in the code? This code is being held up as "state-of-the-art", and yet the system contained at least one critical cryptographic vulnerability - apparently left open for years.

1105380103180050434.text: We don't believe that this trapdoor was deliberately inserted (although if you *did* want to put a backdoor in an election system...) Swiss Post have stated that this *was* a mistake, it was known about since 2017, but that Scytl had failed to fix it:https://www.post.ch/en/about-us/company/media/press-releases/2019/error-in-the-source-code-discovered-and-rectified …

1105379201207554048.text: This finding raises several important questions. This system has apparently been audited multiple times, and both Scytl and Swiss Post have not been shy about their confidence in this system. Why did those audits miss this critical issue?

1105379122581188608.text: I initially commented on this system a few weeks ago. I pointed out several concerning areas that triggered red-flags. Let us take a moment to remember how Scytl and Swiss Post responded to those observations:https://twitter.com/SarahJamieLewis/status/1105186543231131648 …

1105378603582218240.text: As a note: We did not participate in the bug bounty, but we did provide advanced notice of our findings to Swiss Post as a courtesy. I will get into this in a little while.

1105378554525569026.text: I am going to use this thread to provide my own opinions on this issue, and how it fits into the wider context of evoting. It's 1am in Vancouver, but I will be awake for a little while.

1105378345544343552.text: Along with a detailed paper describing the issue (https://people.eng.unimelb.edu.au/vjteague/UniversalVerifiabilitySwissPost.pdf …), we have also released sample false proofs that demonstrate how someone could exploit this trapdoor to change election outcomes.

1105378257317191680.text: It is 9am Swiss Time, @VTeagueAus, Olivier Pereira & I are releasing details of a cryptographic trapdoor that we found in the Swiss Post #evoting system that would allows admins to falsely "prove" mixes that alter votes & undetectably compromise elections: https://people.eng.unimelb.edu.au/vjteague/SwissVote …

1100115807739174912.text: Now I ask: Excluding of all the existential issues with e-voting. Who has the authority to accept security risks identified as part of public voting infrastructure? Because it certainly shouldn't be the people who operate it, or the people who gain power through it.

1100115167034011648.text: That is not security engineering, it is a publicity stunt, and it's really concerning that projects are starting to see it as a way to market themselves as "secure".

1100114818474827776.text:
One of the reasons I dislike public intrusion testing stunts, is that the limited scope results in perverse outcomes:

* If no exploitable issues are found, the project will wave that flag around
* If exploitable issues are found, the project will claim it's battle hardened.

1100113211070722048.text: As such, I've seen projects postponed because both mitigating the risk AND acceptance are too expensive/timely/difficult.

1100113083052236801.text:
In work I've done, the someone with enough authority has been anyone from a line manager to a director, to a VP.

The higher up the chain you go to get a risk assessment the more difficult and costly it becomes.

1100112595028066304.text:
On such an occasion you have 2 possibilities:

1) Change the goal to something that can be secured.
2) Someone with enough authority accepts the risk.

1100112260960120834.text:
When I was a security engineer I always went into projects with the goal of shipping the product, securely. My job was to work out how to achieve something securely.

On occasion though, it turns out that goal is not possible.

1097320105694846977.text:
To bring this back around, compare the election ZKP proof code that  triggered this whole thread, with this not identical, but comparable in  complexity, code from the Dalek libs: 

https://github.com/dalek-cryptography/bulletproofs/blob/main/src/inner_product_proof.rs …

1097316022242033664.text:
The simplest way to make your auditor happy is to not write security sensitive code. If you have to write it, ensure it is well isolated and tested from the surrounding code.

And by well-tested I don't mean "we tested it works", I mean "here is our library of bad inputs"

1097313689261113344.text:
Auditors are often time limited, and if the system is hard to understand then it is by definition hard to audit (and, thus, hard to secure).

If your auditor is spending time trying to work out ground layer things like "what cryptographic parameters are you using" things are bad.

1097311693028225024.text:
Honestly enterprise-style Java is one of the worst domains for auditing security flows because everything little thing is hidden behind an interface, in an impl folder, with injected configuration.

Not to mention the verbosity of java math.

1097309394851647488.text:
One of the reasons I dislike public bug bounty stunts like this election software or across cryptocurrency space is that they focus on exploitation and not systemic soundness.

Anyone can engineer a bug bounty that demonstrates minimal exploitable flaws.

1097307575685500928.text:
On the *never assume good intentions* front: the default return value for authentication/authorization/validation/verification should be false (sometimes it should even be panic())

Most if statements in a security sensitive function should default "return false"

1097305300468523008.text:
And that brings me back to the first point "Fail fast, fail often"

To many systems try to recover from errors, I've seen some systems dedicate entire packages to making bad input safe, when the correct thing to do would be to shutdown that entire flow.

1097303673904889856.text:
Code changes, and someone auditing code is likely considering the potential of introducing future vulnerabilities in a code base is.

Code can be secure, and also fragile.

That is a vital thing to remember.

1097303400557858816.text: And because this is code, we also have to think in more dimensions. What happens when someone decides to patch the system and messes up the fragile integration configuration?

1097302738935767040.text:
More so, the majority of application-level security bugs happen at the intersection of code packages e.g. calling the wrong method, referencing the wrong config file etc.

Even if the isolated code is perfect, the potential for integration misuse is high.

1097302190509572096.text: That last point applies most to my critique thread - it is impossible to audit security sensitive code split across 20 different packages, references 30 different classes and interfaces, and configured at runtime via JSON.

1097301625142538245.text:
There a plenty of books about security driven design, and I'm not going to dive into methodologies. But if you don't like reading then take away this:

* Fail fast, Fail often
* Never assume good intentions
* Don't over decompose security sensitive code.

1097301028662214656.text:
Mistakes happen. All the time. Even the best engineering teams on the planet sometimes screw up.

The goal of security driven design is to minimize the impact of mistakes.

1097300788605374464.text: First, let me make a distinction between "secure" code and "security driven" code. While the primary purpose of most audits is to "find security bugs", the main driver of that work is determining if the code is "security driven".

1097300029016989696.text:
